Expectation1: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation1: Hand-delivering a high-value or sensitive package directly to the recipient and verifying their identity
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: The coordinator emailed a brief suggestion about organizing supplies a different way if time allows.
Story:
I glanced at my phone, double-checking the address and the name for the high-value package in my hands. As a delivery person, I knew the drill: hand it directly to the recipient, verify their ID, and get a signature. No shortcuts, especially with something this important. But as I waited at the door, my mind kept drifting to the community center. I was supposed to volunteer right after my shift, and the coordinator had just emailed a suggestion—if I had time, could I reorganize the supply closet? She’d hinted it would really help, and I wanted to show I was reliable.

The minutes ticked by. No answer at the door, and I couldn’t just leave the package. My phone buzzed again: a reminder from the volunteer coordinator. I felt the pressure mounting—my job demanded I stay until the delivery was complete, but my volunteer role expected me to be flexible and proactive. I could feel the tension in my chest, torn between doing my job by the book and not letting down the team at the center. I stood there, package in hand, caught between two sets of expectations, unsure which responsibility should come first.
